prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7A1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Red side of SiO 7-6,, and continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
The ejecta are ~0.4" in extent, and have Cycle 0 total flux in 12CO 2-1 of 20 mJy. Our non-LTE excitation modeling of ALMA and Herschel line detections (Kamenetzky et al. 2013) predict a CO 3-2 flux of 60mJy. Resolving the ejecta into ~10 beams area at the requested Cycle 1 angular resolution results in predicted Cycle 2 flux of 6 mJy. We want to measure the lines with high S/N and also image the fainter line wings, so require S/N of 20 or 0.3mJy RMS.
Spectral resolution is set by the need to resolve along the line of sight with at least the deconvolved angular resolution in the plane of the sky (~1/2 the beam, or 0.07"). Since the ejeca are in free hypersonic radial expansion, the required velocity resolution is Delta v = Delta z/t = 0.07"*50kpc/27yr =600 km/s. The total FWHM is >2000 km/s so 2 tunings are requred to cover the full line profile to zero intensity in Band 7 (2000 km/s ~ 2.3GHz).
Imaging:
The shocked ring is 2" in diameter, so only the highest resolution configuration is required. The structures of interest are the ejecta (0.4") and the ring thickness (0.2").
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

Sensitivity:
The ejecta are ~0.4" in extent, and have Cycle 0 total flux in 12CO 2-1 of 20 mJy. Our non-LTE excitation modeling of ALMA and Herschel line detections (Kamenetzky et al. 2013) predict a CO 3-2 flux of 60mJy. Resolving the ejecta into ~10 beams area at the requested Cycle 1 angular resolution results in predicted Cycle 2 flux of 6 mJy. We want to measure the lines with high S/N and also image the fainter line wings, so require S/N of 20 or 0.3mJy RMS.
Spectral resolution is set by the need to resolve along the line of sight with at least the deconvolved angular resolution in the plane of the sky (~1/2 the beam, or 0.07"). Since the ejeca are in free hypersonic radial expansion, the required velocity resolution is Delta v = Delta z/t = 0.07"*50kpc/27yr =600 km/s. The total FWHM is >2000 km/s so 2 tunings are requred to cover the full line profile to zero intensity in Band 7 (2000 km/s ~ 2.3GHz).
Imaging:
The shocked ring is 2" in diameter, so only the highest resolution configuration is required. The structures of interest are the ejecta (0.4") and the ring thickness (0.2").
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

Sensitivity:
The ejecta are ~0.4" in extent, and have Cycle 0 total flux in 12CO 2-1 of 20 mJy. Our non-LTE excitation modeling of ALMA and Herschel line detections (Kamenetzky et al. 2013) predict a CO 3-2 flux of 60mJy. Resolving the ejecta into ~10 beams area at the requested Cycle 1 angular resolution results in predicted Cycle 2 flux of 6 mJy. We want to measure the lines with high S/N and also image the fainter line wings, so require S/N of 20 or 0.3mJy RMS.
Spectral resolution is set by the need to resolve along the line of sight with at least the deconvolved angular resolution in the plane of the sky (~1/2 the beam, or 0.07"). Since the ejeca are in free hypersonic radial expansion, the required velocity resolution is Delta v = Delta z/t = 0.07"*50kpc/27yr =600 km/s. The total FWHM is >2000 km/s so 2 tunings are requred to cover the full line profile to zero intensity in Band 7 (2000 km/s ~ 2.3GHz).
Imaging:
The shocked ring is 2" in diameter, so only the highest resolution configuration is required. The structures of interest are the ejecta (0.4") and the ring thickness (0.2").
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

The ejecta are ~0.4" in extent, and have Cycle 0 total flux in 12CO 2-1 of 20 mJy. Our non-LTE excitation modeling of ALMA and Herschel line detections (Kamenetzky et al. 2013) predict a CO 6-5 flux of 600mJy. Resolving the ejecta into ~10 beams area at the requested Cycle 1 angular resolution results in predicted Cycle 2 fluxes of 6 and 60 mJy. We want to measure these with high S/N and also image the fainter line wings, so require S/N of 20 or 3mJy rms.
Spectral resolution is set by the need to resolve along the line of sight with at least the deconvolved angular resolution in the plane of the sky (~1/2 the beam, or 0.07"). Since the ejeca are in free hypersonic radial expansion, the required velocity resolution is Delta v = Delta z/t = 0.07"*50kpc/27yr =600 km/s. The total FWHM is >2000 km/s so 3 tunings are requred to cover the full line profile to zero intensity in Band 9 (2000 km/s ~ 4.6GHz).
Imaging:
The shocked ring is 2" in diameter, but the structures of interest are the ejecta (0.4") and the ring thickness (0.2"), so only the high resolution configuration is required.
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7A2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Blue side of SiO 7-6, and continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity:
The ejecta are ~0.4" in extent, and have Cycle 0 total flux in 12CO 2-1 of 20 mJy. Our non-LTE excitation modeling of ALMA and Herschel line detections (Kamenetzky et al. 2013) predict a CO 3-2 flux of 60mJy. Resolving the ejecta into ~10 beams area at the requested Cycle 1 angular resolution results in predicted Cycle 2 flux of 6 mJy. We want to measure the lines with high S/N and also image the fainter line wings, so require S/N of 20 or 0.3mJy RMS.
Spectral resolution is set by the need to resolve along the line of sight with at least the deconvolved angular resolution in the plane of the sky (~1/2 the beam, or 0.07"). Since the ejeca are in free hypersonic radial expansion, the required velocity resolution is Delta v = Delta z/t = 0.07"*50kpc/27yr =600 km/s. The total FWHM is >2000 km/s so 2 tunings are requred to cover the full line profile to zero intensity in Band 7 (2000 km/s ~ 2.3GHz).
Imaging:
The shocked ring is 2" in diameter, so only the highest resolution configuration is required. The structures of interest are the ejecta (0.4") and the ring thickness (0.2").
Calibration: Default calibration is sufficient.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default accuracy is sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: None
Data Rate: The OT does not report a high data rate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Supernovae drive the evolution of the ISM: they disperse heavy elements, inject mechanical energy, accelerate energetic particles, and create molecules and dust. SN1987A was the closest SN explosion to Earth observed since 1604, a unique target to study supernova and SNR physics.
We will build on our Cycle 0 observations of strong CO and SiO emission, and exploit the high angular resolution of Cycle 2 to create the first 3-d resolved maps of these species in the ejecta of SN1987A, and the temperature and density of the ejecta. We will resolve the predicted clumpy structure, constraining instabilities that occurred during and shortly after the explosion.
We will simultaneously image the high-frequency continuum. Our Cycle 0 observations found a very large mass of dust formed in the ejecta. The relative distribution of dust, CO and SiO emission will constrain dust composition and formation physics.
A high-frequency spectral index map will help resolve the mystery of whether particles are accelerated at the forward or reverse shock, how that nonlinear particle acceleration changes as the shocks interact with the dense circumstellar ring, and the nature of the compact remnant.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 0 high priority #273 - SN 1987A: a Unique Laboratory of Shock and Dust Physics (PI Indebetouw) Cycle 1 high priority #75 - SN 1987A: a Unique Laboratory of Shock and Dust Physics (PI Indebetouw)
